Introduction: Two myths dominate the story of Ja=
pan's relationship
with the outside world. The first and most common is tha=
t Japan was an
isolated country, opened by the arrival of Commodore Perry. =
The second
compares Japan to an oyster, because the foreign influence that =
it
accepted was no bigger than a grain of sand.

In recent years, those myt=
hs have come under attack from researchers
studying medieval communication =
between Kyushu and the Asian
continent. We are delighted to announce the pa=
rticipation of two
authors whose work details a far richer and more complex=
 environment.
Professors Batten and Wang describe a time in which pirates,
=
diplomats, traders, monks and soldiers sailed to and from Japan.

Much of t=
his scholarship is new. For example, Professor Batten
examines the K=F4roka=
n, the official guest-house for foreign visitors,
which was located in Haka=
ta, now located inside the modern-day city of
Fukuoka. A thousand years ago=
, most visitors to Japan would have

and only authorized gateway to

eath the city's baseball

Professor Batten approaches the topic by covering the history of
Hakat=
a from 500 C.E. into the medieval period. He has chapters

diplomacy, piracy, and trade. Professor Batten has

areer focusing on Kyushu and has had access to

scoveries in the area. Chapter 4 of this

g on the particularly

n Hakata in 945,

 those on

d.

Professor Wang's focus is on diplomatic relations and a series of
impor=
tant embassies sent from the Japanese islands to Sui and Tang

xplains in detail the rigorous criteria of the Chinese

in the selection of diplomats and how the two

 He journeys with a party of Japanese

y system
